content:
Lean cannot synthesize Module (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K) without an increase of heartbeats. 

import Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic

open NumberField

variable (K : Type*) [Field K] [NumberField K]

variable (I : Ideal (ğ“ K)) -- OK

variable (M : Submodule (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K)) -- Timeout

Is it something to worry about?

My experience in FLT regular is that ğ“ K is usually very slow to work with, and I use [IsIntegralClosure B A K] whenever possible. And we also had

attribute [local instance 2000] inst_ringOfIntegersAlgebra Algebra.toSMul Algebra.toModule

which would for example make Submodule (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K) instant.

Looking at the trace of the output without these hacks, I guess things would also improve if the ordered-algebraic classes or topological-algebraic classes were scoped. But this might be controversial.
What kind of classes is it looking for? If it's CovariantClass/ContravariantClass, I might have a speedup to offer.

I'm referring to these
image.png
Though I'm not sure these are the culprit yet.
Oh yeah no. Those are fast and sturdy and very very useful everywhere.

In

import Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic

open NumberField

variable (K : Type*) [Field K] [NumberField K]

set_option profiler true
set_option trace.Meta.synthInstance.tryResolve true
set_option trace.Meta.isDefEq true
set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 1000000
set_option maxHeartbeats 10000000000

variable (M : Submodule (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K)) -- Timeout

There is a [12.650751s] âœ… IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K) â‰Ÿ IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K), which looks like lean is having a trouble unifying
Subalgebra.toCommRing with SubringClass.toRing.
Maybe @Anne Baanen knows what's going on?

Oh that's a big issue indeed, worth looking into. Don't know from the top of my head what's going wrong here, the defeq cache is a lot more robust nowadays so I assume it's not the same equality being tested exponentially often, right?
Should we make docs#NumberField.ringOfIntegers irreducible?
You can get away with just set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 50000 if using lean4#2478

Adam Topaz said:

Should we make docs#NumberField.ringOfIntegers irreducible?

If that just means replacing def by irreducible_def in the definition of ringOfIntegers, then it does not help much... It still get a timeout when I try #synth Module (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K)

Andrew just reminded me of this issue in their FLT-regular talk at Lean Together 2024. I think the relevant part of the instance trace is this:

        [tryResolve] [9.838419s] âœ… IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K) â‰Ÿ IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K) â–¼
          [isDefEq] [4.865673s] âœ… IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K) =?= IsDomain â†¥?m.9046 â–¼
            [] [4.865389s] âœ… CommSemiring.toSemiring =?= Ring.toSemiring â–¼
              [] [4.865353s] âœ… Ring.toSemiring =?= Ring.toSemiring â–¼
                [delta] [4.865339s] âœ… Ring.toSemiring =?= Ring.toSemiring â–¼
                  [] [4.865321s] âœ… CommRing.toRing =?= SubringClass.toRing (ğ“ K) â–¼
                    [] [4.865221s] âœ… CommRing.toRing =?= Function.Injective.ring Subtype.val (_ : Function.Injective fun a => â†‘a) (_ : â†‘0 = â†‘0)
                          (_ : â†‘1 = â†‘1) (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(x + x_1) = â†‘(x + x_1))
                          (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(x * x_1) = â†‘(x * x_1)) (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(-x) = â†‘(-x))
                          (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(x - x_1) = â†‘(x - x_1))
                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)) (x_1 : â„•), â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x) = â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x))
                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)) (x_1 : â„¤), â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x) = â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x))
                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)) (x_1 : â„•), â†‘(x ^ x_1) = â†‘(x ^ x_1)) (_ : âˆ€ (x : â„•), â†‘â†‘x = â†‘â†‘x)
                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â„¤), â†‘â†‘x = â†‘â†‘x) â–¶
          [isDefEq] [4.941348s] âœ… ?m.8348 =?= SubringClass.instIsDomainSubtypeMemInstMembershipToSemiringToRing (ğ“ K) â–¶

The thing taking all of the time is checking IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K) â‰Ÿ IsDomain â†¥(ğ“ K), something which looks obvious but the problem is that one of the ring structures is coming from CommSemiring.toSemiring and the other from Ring.toSemiring, and typeclass inference has a habit of sometimes exploding with these kinds of question. The 4.5 seconds is just breaking down into many many tiny goals which then keep exploding again, e.g.

                                  [delta] [0.566770s] âœ… AddGroupWithOne.zsmul =?= AddGroupWithOne.zsmul â–¼
                                    [] [0.566496s] âœ… Function.Injective.addGroupWithOne Subtype.val (_ : Function.Injective fun a => â†‘a) (_ : â†‘0 = â†‘0)
                                          (_ : â†‘1 = â†‘1)
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(Subalgebra.toSubring (ğ“ K))), â†‘(x + x_1) = â†‘(x + x_1))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(Subalgebra.toSubring (ğ“ K))), â†‘(-x) = â†‘(-x))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(Subalgebra.toSubring (ğ“ K))), â†‘(x - x_1) = â†‘(x - x_1))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(Subalgebra.toSubring (ğ“ K))) (x_1 : â„•), â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x) = â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(Subalgebra.toSubring (ğ“ K))) (x_1 : â„¤), â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x) = â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â„•), â†‘â†‘x = â†‘â†‘x)
                                          (_ :
                                            âˆ€ (x : â„¤),
                                              â†‘â†‘x =
                                                â†‘â†‘x) =?= Function.Injective.addGroupWithOne Subtype.val
                                          (_ : Function.Injective fun a => â†‘a) (_ : â†‘0 = â†‘0) (_ : â†‘1 = â†‘1)
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(x + x_1) = â†‘(x + x_1))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(-x) = â†‘(-x))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x x_1 : â†¥(ğ“ K)), â†‘(x - x_1) = â†‘(x - x_1))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)) (x_1 : â„•), â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x) = â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â†¥(ğ“ K)) (x_1 : â„¤), â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x) = â†‘(x_1 â€¢ x))
                                          (_ : âˆ€ (x : â„•), â†‘â†‘x = â†‘â†‘x) (_ : âˆ€ (x : â„¤), â†‘â†‘x = â†‘â†‘x) â–¶

@Matthew Ballard do you understand how to fix these kinds of problems nowadays?

This seems to be a minimal hack which "fixes" the issue:

import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Submodule.Basic
import Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic

variable (K : Type*) [Field K] [NumberField K]

open NumberField

attribute [local instance 1001] Algebra.toModule -- makes it quick; 1000 not good enough

set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 0 in
set_option maxHeartbeats 0 in
set_option trace.profiler true in
variable (M : Submodule (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K))

Matthew Ballard said:

You can get away with just set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 50000 if using lean4#2478

This is the structure flattening I was talking about. This alone does not solve the problem though.

Not the main issue, but I was surprised to run into this in the trace:

Matthew Ballard said:

Getting flashbacks

[] [0.130315s] âŒ apply @Subsemiring.toLinearOrderedSemiring to LinearOrderedSemiring â†¥(CliffordAlgebra.even Q) â–¼

Here's the fix which demotes the bad instance rather than promotes the good one:

import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Submodule.Basic
import Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic

variable (K : Type*) [Field K] [NumberField K]

open NumberField

attribute [local instance 909] Subalgebra.module' -- 910 no good

variable (M : Submodule (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K))

  S.toSubmodule.module'

and then trying everything to get SMul K â„¤

I occasionally come back to this question. Here is a summary of the issue (or at least, one of the issues):

import Mathlib.Tactic

variable (K : Type) [Field K] [NumberField K]

open NumberField

-- #synth SMul (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K) -- times out

set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 70000 in -- fails at 60000
set_option trace.Meta.synthInstance true in
set_option trace.profiler true in
#synth SMul (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K) -- fails without instance maxHeartbeats bump

This kind of failure makes working with integers of number fields very difficult. There are other variants, e.g. if LLL is also a number field and a KKK-algebra, then SMul (ğ“ K) (ğ“ L) also takes forever, even though Algebra (ğ“ K) (ğ“ L) is fast.

What I've discovered whilst sitting jetlagged in a hotel in Singapore at 5am is that the problem is the following: Because ğ“ K is actually a term of type Subalgebra \Z K, the goal is really SMul â†¥(ğ“ K) â†¥(ğ“ K). Typeclass inference can find 15 or so instances which apply, but among them are the deadly instances Submonoid.smul, Subsemiring.smul , and the poorly-named Subalgebra.instSMulSubtypeMemSubalgebraInstMembershipInstSetLikeSubalgebra which should really be called Subalgebra.smul. The type of Submonoid.smul is basically [SMul M' Î±] (S : Submonoid M') : SMul (â†¥S) Î± and you can now guess what the others are. These do look good syntactically for a goal of SMul â†¥(ğ“ K) â†¥(ğ“ K), but they are deadly because they leave a goal of the form SMul K (ğ“ K) and this takes 2.5 seconds to fail on my machine.

So now I realise that this is the same problem as #synth SMul â„‚ â„ that we saw in another thread, although this is even worse because it takes even longer to give up.

In this situation it is extremely difficult to steer typeclass inference away from ever running into the goal SMul K (ğ“ K), so the question is whether it is possible to make it fail quickly. 

import Mathlib.Tactic

variable (K : Type) [Field K] [NumberField K]

open NumberField

set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 70000 in
set_option trace.Meta.synthInstance true in
set_option trace.profiler true in
#synth SMul K (ğ“ K) -- fails after thousands of lines of nonsense
Thanks for looking at this. If you want a concrete example to work on, in #11792 there is a discussion about a rather slow file.
BTW, is there a simple way of profiling a file? I mean, set_option profiler true gives information about any single declaration, I would like to have the total.
If you do lake build <Module> in the terminal (on a file containing set_option profiler true near the beginning), it also prints a summary at the end.

Kevin Buzzard said:

In this situation it is extremely difficult to steer typeclass inference away from ever running into the goal SMul K (ğ“ K), so the question is whether it is possible to make it fail quickly.

You could try to remove the instance attribute locally from the instance leading to the problematic SMul K (ğ“ K) search (or reduce its priority). You could possibly also try to increase the priority of the instance you want to trigger. Or you could make (local) shortcut instances for SMul (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K)and SMul (ğ“ K) (ğ“ L).

I've been working on one of the very slow Mathlib files to see if I can speed it up, and I'll report on this soon somewhere here. Stay tuned!

I believe there's a better solution: Replace

def ringOfIntegers : Subalgebra â„¤ K := integralClosure â„¤ K

by

def ringOfIntegers : Type _ := integralClosure â„¤ K
Then your TC goals will be Submodule (ğ“ K) (ğ“ K) rather than Submodule â†¥(ğ“ K) â†¥(ğ“ K) and will match many less instances.
Of course, this comes at the cost of ğ“ K not being a Subalgebra anymore, but the coercion to Type _ of one.
I was also thinking about this... I will try to see how annoying it is.
Another approach that we could try is to give the â†¥ coercion a different name for each setlike, instead of docs#SetLike.instCoeSortType.
Wouldn't Lean still try to unfold them?

I mean like we already do for coes:

def coeSort (s : MySubobject X) : Type* :=
  { x : X // x âˆˆ s }

instance : CoeSort (MySubobject X) Type* :=
  âŸ¨coeSortâŸ©
(Presumably using a @[coeSort] attribute to do delaboration.)
Then the discrimination tree can index on MySubobject.coeSort and we don't have the billion candidate instances.
Oh sorry, I misunderstood. Yes, that sounds reasonable.
One drawback of my idea is that all the instances on Subtype have to be copied over manually: LE, Coe, Mul, ...

Yeah, I don't see this working out. For example docs#MulMemClass.subtype must use the generic CoeSort instance, and docs#Subsemigroup.topEquiv_toMulHom must use the specific. We're definitely going to get type errors this way.
I think I'll try out YaÃ«l's plan instead. Defining RingOfIntegers as a Type instead of a Subalgebra is probably the least destructive alternative.

I'm hitting a related timeout currently working with residue fields. Is there a good way of resolving?

import Mathlib

open Valued

variable (K : Type*) [Field K] {Î“â‚€ : outParam Type*}
    [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero Î“â‚€] [vK : Valued K Î“â‚€]

example (n : â„•) : Module ğ’ª[K] (ğ“‚[K] ^ n : Ideal ğ’ª[K]) := Submodule.module _
example (n : â„•) : Module ğ’ª[K] (ğ“‚[K] ^ n : Ideal ğ’ª[K]) := by infer_instance -- timeout
Might have to do with Valued.ResidueField being a def (even reducible) and not an abbrev?

The keys for the goal are #[Module, Subtype, _uniq.26983, â—¾, Subtype, Subtype, _uniq.26983, â—¾, â—¾, *, *] but we have a lot of instances like docs#LieSubmodule.module' with weak keys like #[Module, *, Subtype, *, â—¾, *, *].

Of course, we have no Lie algebra structure in play but it because the keys match Lean then tries to synthesize the instance parameters and unify against a LieSubmodule. The signature is 

{R : Type u} â†’
  {L : Type v} â†’
    {M : Type w} â†’
      [inst : CommRing R] â†’
        [inst_1 : LieRing L] â†’
          [inst_2 : AddCommGroup M] â†’
            [inst_3 : _root_.Module R M] â†’
              [inst_4 : LieRingModule L M] â†’
                (N : LieSubmodule R L M) â†’
                  {S : Type u_1} â†’
                    [inst_5 : Semiring S] â†’
                      [inst_6 : SMul S R] â†’
                        [inst_7 : _root_.Module S M] â†’ [inst_8 : IsScalarTower S R M] â†’ _root_.Module S â†¥â†‘N

so this takes some time.

There are quite few of these instances of Module on subtypes with weak keys so it adds. Especially because both the arguments to Module are coerced from subtypes.

Two quick workarounds: (1) set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 40000 and it works (2) don't import Lie algebras and other things making typeclass inference go off the rails, 

import Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Valued.ValuedField

open Valued

variable (K : Type*) [Field K] {Î“â‚€ : outParam Type*}
    [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero Î“â‚€] [vK : Valued K Î“â‚€]
#synth Semiring ğ’ª[K]
example (n : â„•) : Module ğ’ª[K] (ğ“‚[K] ^ n : Ideal ğ’ª[K]) := Submodule.module _
-- set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 40000
-- set_option trace.Meta.synthInstance true
-- set_option trace.profiler true
count_heartbeats in -- 15457
example (n : â„•) : Module ğ’ª[K] (ğ“‚[K] ^ n : Ideal ğ’ª[K]) := by infer_instance
variable (n : â„•) in
#synth Module ğ’ª[K] (ğ“‚[K] ^ n : Ideal ğ’ª[K]) -- modern way to do the last line

takes under 1/2 as long.

In my opinion the right long-term fix for this is to redefine ğ’ª[K] as a Type not a Subring. I might be saying the same thing as Matt but my understanding of the problem is that because the goal is actually Module â†¥ğ’ª[K] â†¥(ğ“‚[K] ^ n), Lean is constantly being sidetracked with ideas of the form "ooh we need to prove ClassName â†¥X Y and (X : Subring X') so we could perhaps make progress by finding a term of type ClassName X' Y." This idea is almost always a disaster in the sense that it might take some time to fail because Mathlib is now big, and there are lots of classes.

Rereading Matt's response I think it says the same thing as mine but in a more sophisticated way.

See here for how I designed finite adele rings not as subalgebras but as types, to avoid this kind of problem.

Mario Carneiro said:

One thing I just noticed is that docs#SetLike.instCoeSortType directly uses a lambda and membership:

instance (priority := 100) : CoeSort A (Type _) :=
  âŸ¨fun p => { x : B // x âˆˆ p }âŸ©

Since this is a coercion, it is unfolded and therefore loads of mathlib terms contain these explicit lambdas. (This also needs a dedicated delaborator, written just below it.) Has anyone tried replacing this with a call to a setToType function? The specific reason I have to believe that this will improve performance across the library is that I can see failed instance searches caused by the fact that the indexing is not able to handle the lambdas: if I have definitions foo, bar : Subgroup G then CommGroup â†‘foo also attempts to apply an instance for CommGroup â†‘bar. Normally this would not happen because the discrimination tree can tell them apart, but after the aforementioned elaboration the result is CommGroup {x // x âˆˆ foo} vs CommGroup {x // x âˆˆ bar} and lean gives up indexing at the lambda.

Will make do

My understanding: we have the following values for the keys 

inductive Key where
  | const : Name â†’ Nat â†’ Key
  | fvar  : FVarId â†’ Nat â†’ Key
  | lit   : Literal â†’ Key
  | star  : Key
  | other : Key
  | arrow : Key
  | proj  : Name â†’ Nat â†’ Nat â†’ Key

Currently docs#Lean.Meta.DiscrTree.mkPath sends e.getAppFn to .other for the cases

(Expr.mdata (KVMap.mk _) _)
(Expr.letE _ _ _ _ _)
(Expr.lam _ _ _ _)
(Expr.app _ _)
(Expr.sort _)
(Expr.bvar _)

In particular, anything hiding inside of a .lam is just crunched down to .other. As Mario explained above, with the current ordered of Membership.mem we have a lambda at the head of any coercion of a subtype to sort.

Reversing the order, the head becomes Membership.mem, which being a constant, gets placed into the keys itself and indexing can go deeper to generate more refined keys.
That non-keying of lambda I had understood, but I had not thought of looking up SetLike.instCoeSortType

It is a fairly subtle change when just looking at the expression pretty printed. After all, you only see two things get swapped. But if you are better than me at reading off the Expr it is perhaps more obvious.

In "fixing" mathlib, the worst offender is just the standard docs#Set.CoeSortType. Interestingly if you look at the porting note for it, you see that docs#Set.Elem is introduced to solve a similar indexing problem but for norm_cast. But since it is a essentially an abbrev the indexing for keys just unfolds and marches on.
